• The campus-based programs, including FSEOG, FWS, and Perkins Loan, were created to provide financial aid to students who demonstrated financial need. These programs are unique in that they are designed to target students with the highest need and are based on institution-specific award criteria rather than non-discretionary award criteria such as Pell Grants and Direct Loans. The campus-based programs' authorizations of appropriations, along with many other provisions under the Higher Education Act, expired at the end of FY2015. The FSEOG and FWS programs have continued to be funded through annual appropriation bills, most recently through the Continuing Appropriations Act 2018 (P.L. 115-56 ), which extended funding for the programs through December 8, 2017. The Perkins Loan program was amended and extended through FY2017 under the Federal Perkins Loan Program Extension Act of 2015 (Extension Act; P.L. 114-105 ). The Extension Act prohibits future appropriations for the Perkins Loan program and prohibits an automatic extension of it under the General Education Provisions Act (GEPA; P.L. 90-247, as amended). The campus-based programs are among the oldest of the federal financial aid programs. As federal aid has largely transitioned to a system that allows for "portability" in receipt of student aid, meaning that most forms of aid are made available to students at whichever participating institution a student chooses to attend, the campus-based programs have come to play a relatively smaller role in the federal student aid effort. For example, of the approximately $125 billion of federal aid that was made available to students through programs authorized under the HEA in FY2016, 76% was through the Direct Loan program, 21% through the Pell Grant program, and 2% through the campus-based aid programs. The HEA authorizes most of the federal programs that provide direct financial aid to postsecondary students. As lawmakers consider reauthorization of the HEA, several issues related to the campus-based programs may be considered. These include the extent to which the campus-based programs provide types of aid to students that are not provided via other postsecondary aid programs, whether the current formula for allocating funds to institutions is optimal, and the potential role of the campus-based aid programs in a redesigned federal aid system. Water Infrastructure Security: A Comprehensive Overview * Water infrastructure systems, including dams, reservoirs, aqueducts, and pipes, are critical to the nation's water supply, transportation, and electricity infrastructure. These systems are vulnerable to terrorist attacks, including physical disruption, bioterrorism/chemical contamination, and cyber attacks. Damage or destruction by terrorist attack could disrupt the delivery of vital human services, endanger public health and the environment, or cause loss of life.
* Since most water infrastructure is government-owned, it may serve as a symbolic and political target for some. This report presents an overview of the large and diverse sector, describes security-related actions by the government and private sector since 9/11, and discusses additional policy issues and responses, including congressional interest.
* The potential for terrorism is not new. In 1941, Federal Bureau of Investigation Director J. Edgar Hoover wrote, "It has long been recognized that among public utilities, water supply facilities offer a particularly vulnerable point of attack to the foreign agent, due to the strategic position they occupy in keeping the wheels of industry turning and in preserving the health and morale of the American populace."
* Water infrastructure systems also are highly linked with other infrastructure systems, especially electric power and transportation, as well as the chemical industry which supplies treatment chemicals, making security of all of them an issue of concern. These types of vulnerable interconnections were evident, for example, during the August 2003 electricity blackout in the Northeast United States: wastewater treatment plants in Cleveland, Detroit, New York, and other locations that lacked backup generation systems lost power and discharged millions of gallons of untreated sewage during the emergency, and power failures at drinking water plants led to boil-water advisories in many communities. Likewise, natural disasters such as the 2005 Gulf Coast hurricanes and 2007 Mississippi River floods caused extensive and costly damage to multiple infrastructure systems—transportation, water, electric power, and telecommunications. Broadly speaking, water infrastructure systems include surface and ground water sources of untreated water for municipal, industrial, agricultural, and household needs; dams, reservoirs, aqueducts, and pipes that contain and transport raw water; treatment facilities that remove contaminants from raw water; finished water reservoirs; systems that distribute water to users; and wastewater collection and treatment facilities. <summary> Perkins IV, the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006, amends and revises the Perkins Act. It authorizes "such sums as may be necessary" for FY2007-FY2012 for Perkins Act programs and activities. The act refers to career and technical education (CTE) rather than vocational and technical education. Perkins IV retains the overall purpose of the act, making technical changes. Perkins IV requires the Secretary to reserve funds for certain purposes from funds appropriated under Section 9. Changes in the state allotment formula and the substate formula for distribution of funds for secondary school CTE programs are also made. Perkins IV requires eligible recipients to accept state-adjusted levels of performance or negotiate their own adjusted levels of performance with the eligible agency for each of the core indicators of performance at the secondary and postsecondary levels. Perkins IV also specifies substate formulas for distribution of Perkins grant funds to eligible recipients (Sections 131 and 132). Perkins IV requires eligible recipients to establish measures for each of the indicators. Perkins IV specifies, however, that measures of student attainment may include student achievement on technical assessments that are aligned with industry-recognized standards, if such assessments are available and relevant. Perkins IV also adds five core indicators of performance at the postsecondary level. Perkins IV requires eligible recipients to negotiate adjusted levels of performance for each of the core indicators for which they will be held responsible. Perkins IV also requires eligible recipients to establish levels of performance for each of the core indicators in their local plans. Perkins IV also requires eligible agencies and recipients to disaggregate the data for each of the indicators of performance, including any additional indicators selected by the eligible agency or recipient, based on the categories of students included in Title I-A of the ESEA for data reporting purposes. Perkins IV also retains the exception for technical assistance to eligible recipients to implement improvement plans. Perkins IV requires that funds withheld from an eligible agency be used only to provide technical assistance, assist in the development of an improved state improvement plan, or other relevant improvement activities to benefit the state. Perkins IV also requires that funds withheld from an eligible agency be used only to provide services and activities to students in the area that would have otherwise been served by the eligible recipient. Perkins IV retains the exception for financial sanctions due to exceptional or uncontrollable circumstances or a precipitous and unforseen decline in the state's financial resources. Perkins IV subjects eligible recipients to similar financial sanctions as imposed on eligible agencies. Perkins

<summary>Summary of Major Provisions of the Federal Estate, Gift, and Generation-Skipping Transfer Taxes for 2014</summary>
The federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes for 2014 were phased out over a 10-year period, leaving the gift tax as the only federal transfer tax in 2010. The Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 temporarily reinstated the estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes with lower top rates and larger exemptions. The American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 permanently extended the estate tax rules, except for the top tax rate, which increased from 35% to 40%. The federal estate and gift taxes are unified as they utilize the same rate structure. The federal estate tax is a tax on the estate of a decedent, levied against and paid by the estate. The inheritance tax is imposed on and paid by the heirs of the decedent based upon the money or property that they receive. The determination of federal estate tax liability involves a series of adjustments and modifications of a tax base known as the "gross estate." Certain allowable deductions reduce the gross estate to the "taxable estate." The total of all lifetime taxable gifts made by the decedent is added to the taxable estate before tax rates are applied. The result is the decedent's estate tax which, after reduction for certain allowable credits, is the amount of tax paid by the estate. • The report examines the complexity of border and transportation security challenges, highlighting the need for layered approaches to achieve BTS.
• Current programs and policies in place, such as the CCP, I-68 program, and ISIS, reflect some layering.
• The report suggests that a layered approach to BTS may involve applying security efforts to almost every point of vulnerability or opportunity.
• The report notes that the legacy Customs Service and now CBP have been engaged in a long-term effort to develop a new automated system to process and track goods into the country.
• The report highlights the need for improved border security measures to facilitate legitimate travel and trade, while also addressing potential vulnerabilities.
• The report suggests that a North American Perimeter Security concept, similar to the P.L. 107-173 study, may be necessary to address the challenges of border security.
• The report emphasizes the importance of addressing the complex challenges of border and transportation security, including the need for layered approaches and improved border security measures.

<summary>
• Cabo Verde, a small island nation in West Africa, has a long history of ties with the United States. It is a key transshipment point for cocaine destined for Europe, and its location has made it a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic between Africa and the United States.
• Cabo Verde's political system considers its large expatriate population, which includes expatriates from the United States, to be a key source of private investment and hard currency. Expatriates may vote in national elections, although in presidential elections their collective vote may constitute no more than a fifth of all votes cast within the national territory.
• Cabo Verde's transition to democracy is widely seen as successful and enduring, and as having engendered a generally consensus-based polity. While in power in the 1990s, the MPD pursued an economic reform-focused agenda, seeking to privatize state-owned firms, reform public spending, alleviate poverty, boost social services, and promote exports. It also sought to promote political pluralism and increase and diversify trade and development relations with other countries.
• Cabo Verde has a high literacy rate and generally high social services and health indicators, although they are lower in rural areas and some high-density urban areas. Poverty has decreased since the 1990s, but remains a challenge. The share of Cabo Verdeans living in poverty declined from 37% in 2002 to 27% in 2010 (more recent data is lacking), and extreme poverty rates have dropped as well.
• Cabo Verde is a member of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and is a participant in the Young African Leaders Initiative (YALI). It is also a member of the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) and has received limited assistance under the West Africa Regional Security Initiative (WARSI).
• Cabo Verde has received limited assistance under the West Africa Regional Security Initiative (WARSI), a State Department regional program that seeks to help countries promote adherence to the rule of law, improve criminal justice systems, combat transnational organized crime—including drug trafficking—and promote stability, among other related goals.
• Cabo Verde has received limited assistance under the West Africa Regional Security Initiative (WARSI), a State Department regional program that seeks to help countries promote adherence to the rule of law, improve criminal justice systems, combat transnational organized crime—including drug trafficking—and promote stability, among other related goals.

<summary>
The United States and New Zealand have returned to a high level of security cooperation, forging a new security partnership between the two countries. The two nations, which fought together in many of America's wars and established the Australia-New Zealand-United States (ANZUS) alliance in 1951, are once again close security partners in the Asia Pacific and beyond. New Zealand's nuclear policies in the mid-1980s that prohibited nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships from entering New Zealand ports led the United States to restrict bilateral defense cooperation with New Zealand. For many years this difference largely defined the relationship between the two nations. Recent developments, while not restoring the formal alliance relationship, have greatly bolstered practical aspects of the two nation's bilateral defense and security cooperation as well as reaffirmed an overall close United States bilateral relationship with New Zealand. The extent to which the nuclear issue had been put into the past was demonstrated when President Obama invited Prime Minister John Key to attend the Nuclear Summit in April 2010 and stated that New Zealand had "well and truly earned a place at the table. " New Zealand was the only non-nuclear state invited to the conference. Several organizations and groups, some involving Members of Congress, help promote bilateral ties between the United States and New Zealand, including the United States-New Zealand Council in Washington, DC, and its counterpart, the New Zealand-United States Council in Wellington; the Friends of New Zealand Congressional Caucus and its New Zealand parliamentary counterpart; and the more recent Pacific Partnership Forum. The U.S.-N.Z. Council was established in 1986 to promote cooperation between the two countries and works with government agencies and business groups to this end. The bipartisan Friends of New Zealand Congressional Caucus was launched by former Representatives Jim Kolbe, Ellen Tauscher, and 52 other Members in February 2005. The caucus has included over 60 Members of Congress. Representative Kevin Brady has since replaced Kolbe as the Republican co-chair of the caucus. The Democrat co-chair, Representative Rick Larsen, replaced Ellen Tauscher when she left the House. The first Partnership Forum was held in April 2006. The next Partnership Forum meeting is scheduled for May 2013. The Wellington Declaration of 2010 was a key turning point in United States-New Zealand relations. It built on ongoing improvements in the relationship to enable a reorientation of the bilateral relationship that has put aside past differences to focus on the present

* The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods by which Presidents may appoint officers of the United States: either with the advice and consent of the Senate, or unilaterally "during the Recess of the Senate." These two constitutional provisions have long served as sources of political tension between Presidents and Congresses.
* The Recess Appointments Clause authorizes the President to fill up all Vacancies that may happen during the Recess of the Senate, by granting Commissions which shall expire at the End of their next Session. However, the Senate fell seven votes shy of the 60-vote threshold necessary to reach cloture and move to a vote on the nomination.
* The Senate, at various times during the 112 th Congress, has held "pro forma" sessions, which are intended, at least in part, to prevent the existence of a Senate recess sufficient to permit the President to exercise his constitutional authority to unilaterally appoint officers.
* The pro forma sessions typically last for a single Senator gaveling in the session and, shortly thereafter, gaveling the session out. On December 17, 2011, the Senate adopted a unanimous consent agreement that scheduled a series of pro forma sessions to occur from December 20, 2011, until January 23, 2012.
* The pro forma sessions were held in the traditional August recess of a first session of Congress. However, the pro forma sessions were held in the second session of the 112 th Congress, which began on January 3, 2012.

<summary>Expedited removal under INA Section 235(b)(1) was implemented for arriving aliens, including those who arrived by sea, within designated ports of entry, and those who were apprehended within 100 miles of the border. The agency expanded the reach of expedited removal to include aliens who were unlawfully present in the United States within 100 miles of the border, and those who were apprehended within 14 days of entering the country. The INS and DHS implemented expedited removal for aliens who were physically present in the United States without being admitted or paroled, and who could not establish their continuous physical presence in this country for up to two years. The agency also extended expedited removal to border areas, including those where there was an urgent need to enhance the nation's land borders and deter foreign nationals from dangerous activities.</summary>

The legal framework for congressional redistricting involves constitutional and federal statutory requirements, including the standard for equality of population among districts, the Voting Rights Act (VRA), and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause. The Supreme Court has interpreted these requirements to require congressional districts to be drawn with precision or equality among districts, with a maximum population deviation of 5.97% in 2016. The Court has also clarified that partisan goals can justify deviations from precise equality, but these must be justified by state interests and not by compliance with the VRA.

• Wildfire management costs have risen substantially in recent years, with higher costs being attributed to increased fuel loads on federal lands and the growing number of homes and people in and near forests.
• The high cost of wildfire management has led to increased borrowing from other accounts, including the K-V Fund and other mandatory spending accounts.
• The declining effectiveness of wildfire suppression efforts has led to questions about the effectiveness of fire suppression.
• The Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2000 (HFRA) established an expedited process for environmental review and public involvement in fuel reduction activities.
• The FS and DOI established categorical exclusions from NEPA for hazardous fuel reduction activities.
• The proportion of fuel treatments in the WUI increased after FY2001, from 37% to about 60% from FY2003 to FY2006.
• The FS and DOI have received funding for biomass grants and the Forest Biomass to Energy Program.
• The Bush Administration finalized regulations authorizing NEPA categorical exclusions for post-fire rehabilitation activities affecting up to 4,200 acres.
• The Collaborative Forest Landscape Restoration Act was included as Title IV in the Omnibus Public Lands Management Act of 2009.
• The Obama Administration requested funding for the BAER program as part of a new line item within the National Forest System appropriation account.
• The data show that the average acreage burned annually for 1990-1999 and 2000-2009 was 3.32 million acres, with the six biggest fire seasons of the past 50 years occurring in the past decade.

• Mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees would eliminate the need for the WEP and GPO provisions of Social Security law, which are unpopular among the public and pose administrative difficulties for SSA.
• States and local governments could consider maintaining the current pension structure for newly hired employees or providing a different benefit structure for employees within existing plans.
• Some states and localities might opt to freeze their pension plans to new hires, while others could offer new DB pension plans with different benefits.
• Increased costs could arise from states operating multiple pension plans or different benefit structures within a single plan.
• The impact on pension plans would depend on the type of pension benefit structure governments adopt in response to mandatory participation in Social Security.
• Factors affecting pension plan contributions include the 6.2% Social Security payroll tax paid by employers, employee contributions, and the amount of contributions made by employees.
• Some states and localities are facing revenue shortfalls and may be reluctant to set aside funds for pension benefits payable several years in the future.
• The potential legal issues associated with mandatory Social Security coverage are beyond the scope of this report.

* TAA (Trade Adjustment Assistance) provides federal assistance to workers who involuntarily lose their jobs due to foreign competition. Eligible workers receive funding for training and reemployment services as well as income support while enrolled in training. Workers may also be eligible for other benefits, including a tax credit equal to a portion of qualified health insurance premiums. TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA, Title IV of P.L. 114-27). Reduced barriers to international trade are widely acknowledged to offer benefits to consumers in the form of increased choices and lower prices. Expanded trade may also offer expansionary opportunities to firms that produce goods or services that see increased exports. Reduced barriers to trade may, however, have concentrated negative effects on domestic industries and workers that face increased competition. TAA is designed to provide readjustment assistance to workers who suffer dislocation (job loss) due to foreign competition or offshoring. Generally, TAA provides a more robust set of benefits and services than would be available to a worker who lost his or her job for reasons other than foreign competition. TAA is designed to assist workers who have been adversely affected by reduced trade barriers and increased trade. Its availability to workers who are adversely affected by declines in international trade may be limited. TAA was created in 1962 and, historically, has been reauthorized alongside expansionary trade policies. A detailed legislative history of the program is in the Appendix. In June 2015, TAA was reauthorized by TAARA. The eligibility and benefit provisions of TAARA are authorized to continue through June 30, 2021. TAARA was part of a bill that extended other trade-related policies. TAARA was also passed in conjunction with a separate bill that reauthorized the Trade Promotion Authority (TPA, Title I of P.L. 114-26). TPA (also known as "fast track") grants the President authority to negotiate trade agreements, which are then subject to an "up or down" vote in Congress. Since the reauthorization of TPA in 2015, Congress has not voted on any presidentially negotiated trade agreements. This report focuses on the eligibility and benefit provisions of TAA as enacted by TAARA. These provisions apply to all workers certified for TAA after the law's enactment. The law also had retroactivity provisions and, in some cases, workers who were parts of groups certified prior

* ARRA provided $1.1 billion to the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) for comparative effectiveness research, which is to be used to support research that compares clinical outcomes, effectiveness, and appropriateness of preventive, diagnostic, and therapeutic items, services, and procedures.
* ARRA also provided $300 million to AHRQ to invest in CER activities, $400 million was transferred to NIH, and $400 million is allocated at the discretion of the Secretary.

• The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (P.L. 106-78, Title IX; LMR) requires that meat packers report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). Authority for mandatory reporting was set to expire on September 30, 2015. Livestock industry stakeholders supported the reauthorization of the act, and producer groups put forward proposals amending mandatory reporting.
• The House passed a reauthorization bill (H.R. 2051) in June 2015. In September 2015, the Senate amended the House-passed bill, and Congress reauthorized LMR until September 30, 2020, in the enacted Agriculture Reauthorizations Act of 2015 (P.L. 114-54).
• Before livestock mandatory price reporting was enacted by Congress in 1999, the USDA's Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) collected livestock and meat price and related market information from meat packers on a voluntary basis under the authority of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 (7 U.S.C. §1621 et seq.).
• AMS market reporters collected and reported prices from livestock auctions, feedlots, and packing plants. The information was disseminated through hundreds of daily, weekly, monthly, and annual written and electronic USDA reports on sales of live cattle, hogs, and sheep and wholesale meat products from these animals.
• The goal was to provide all buyers and sellers with accurate and objective market information. By the 1990s, the livestock industry had undergone many sweeping changes, including increased concentration in meat packing and animal feeding, more production specialization, and more vertical integration (firms controlling more than one aspect of production). Fewer animals were sold through negotiated (cash; or "spot") sales, and more frequently sold under alternative marketing arrangements (e.g., formula sales based on a negotiated price established in the future) with prices not publicly disclosed or reported. Some livestock producers, believing such arrangements made it difficult or impossible for them to determine "fair" market prices for livestock going to slaughter, called for mandatory price reporting for packers and others who process and market meat.

* The United States Constitution does not provide for or authorize the recall of any United States officials, including Senators, Representatives, or the President or Vice President. * Members of Congress may have their services ended before their constitutional terms of office expire by their resignation, death, or by action of the House of Representatives in which they sit by way of an expulsion or by a finding that a subsequent public office accepted by a Member is "incompatible" with congressional office (and that the Member has thus vacated their seat in Congress). * The recall of Members of Congress was considered during the drafting of the federal Constitution, but no such provisions were included in the final version sent to the states for ratification. * The idea of placing a recall provision in the Constitution died for lack of support. * The Constitution and congressional practice do not provide for or authorize the recall of Senators or Representatives. * The required qualifications, as well as the disqualifications, to serve in Congress were intentionally kept at a minimum by the framers of the Constitution to allow the people broad discretion to send whom they wish to represent them in Congress. * Officers and employees of the United States, including Members of Congress, do not forfeit federal pensions for which they qualify if convicted of a federal crime that relates to disclosure of classified information, espionage, sabotage, treason, misprision of treason, rebellion or insurrection, seditious conspiracy, harboring or concealing persons, gathering or transmitting defense information, perjury in relation to those offenses, and other designated offenses relating to secrets and national security offenses against the United States. * The forfeiture provisions of this law will apply if the criminal misconduct was engaged in while the individual was a Member of Congress (or while the individual was the President, Vice President, or an elected official of a state or local government), and if every element of the offense "directly relates to the performance of the individual's official duties as a Member, the President, the Vice President, or an elected official of a State or local government."

• The increased presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and in the scientific workforce has been and continues to be of concern to some in the scientific community. Enrollment of U.S. citizens in graduate science and engineering programs has not kept pace with that of foreign students in those programs. A significant number of university faculty in the scientific disciplines are foreign, and foreign doctorates are employed in large numbers by industry. Those in the scientific community, arguing for ceilings on admissions for immigrants, maintain that foreign students use U.S. graduate education programs as stepping stones to immigration through sponsorships for legal permanent residence. Approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remain in the United States, with many eventually becoming citizens. Data on adjustments from temporary visas to permanent status reveal that approximately 6 in 10 new permanent residents occurred in both 2007 and 2008 from adjustments of status admissions. In 2008, approximately 15.0% of those individuals awarded legal permanent resident status resulted from employment-based preferences. Few will dispute that U.S. workers are adversely affected by the entry of foreign scientists and engineers, who reportedly accept lower wages than U.S. citizens would accept in order to enter or remain in the United States. These arguments occur in the context of a debate on projections and potential imbalances in certain scientific and technical disciplines. The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that between the years 2006 and 2016, employment in science and engineering fields will increase at a faster rate than other professional groups. The growth rate will result, primarily, from growth in mathematics and computer-related occupations. Much attention in the scientific community has focused on the H-1B temporary admissions program. A report of the National Science Foundation (NSF) during the late 1980s claiming a nationwide shortage of scientists and engineers may have contributed to the decision by Congress to expand the skilled-labor preference system contained in the Immigration Act of 1990. The 1990 legislation more than doubled employment-based immigration, including scientists and engineers entering under the H-1B visa category. The act raised the numerical limits or ceilings on permanent, employment-based admissions, from 54,000 to 140,000 annually. In addition, the legislation ascribed high priority to the entry of selected skilled and professional workers, and simplified admissions procedures for foreign nationals seeking to temporarily work, study,

• The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) provides funding for renewable energy and end-use energy efficiency technology research, development, and implementation. The funding level Congress decides to provide for FY2018 could impact goals set by EERE and priorities identified in the Administration's FY2018 budget request. President Trump submitted his FY2018 budget request to Congress on May 23, 2017. The budget requests $28.2 billion for DOE, a decrease of nearly $3 billion, or 9.5%, from the FY2017 enacted level. Nearly half of the reduction ($1.5 billion) in the DOE budget request would come from EERE programs. The request specifies two EERE program eliminations: the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program. The funding level Congress provides could affect continued support for these programs and other efforts within EERE including sustainable transportation, renewable energy, and energy efficiency. This report discusses the FY2018 EERE budget request and the proposed EERE funding levels and priorities in the related E&W appropriations bills. It does not discuss the opportunities, challenges, economic value, or commercial status of the various renewable energy technologies and energy efficiency initiatives selected by EERE, nor does it delve into the goals of the individual EERE programs or congressional oversight of certain EERE issues. EERE leads the DOE's effort to support research, accelerate development, and facilitate deployment of energy efficiency and renewable energy technologies. EERE is led by the Assistant Secretary for Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, and it is organized into four offices: Office of Transportation, Office of Renewable Power, Office of Energy Efficiency, and Office of Operations. EERE contends that it invests in what it considers to be the highest-impact activities. The office collaborates with industry, academia, national laboratories, and others to develop technology-specific road maps and then focuses funding on early stage R&D, technology validation and risk-reduction activities, and the reduction of barriers to the adoption of market-ready new technologies. EERE also manages a portfolio of research and development programs that support state and local governments, tribes, and schools. In addition, EERE oversees the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL)—the only national laboratory solely dedicated to researching and developing renewable energy and energy efficiency technologies. EERE funding is provided from the annual E&W appropriations bill. During the last several years of the Obama Administration, the budget request sought to increase funding to support EERE programs

* Cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, Ether, and Litecoin, are digital money that operates as a payment system in an electronic payment system. They are decentralized and use public ledgers to validate transactions. Cryptocurrencies are not legal tender and do not have intrinsic value. They are used as a medium of exchange, a unit of account, and a store of value. Cryptocurrencies have the potential to facilitate criminal activities and lack consumer protections. Cryptocurrencies are subject to network effects, where their value and usefulness depend on how many people are willing to use them. Cryptocurrencies are subject to regulatory challenges, including the potential for them to facilitate criminal activities and lack of consumer protections. Cryptocurrencies are subject to the same regulatory challenges as traditional money systems, including the potential for them to facilitate criminal activities and lack of consumer protections. * Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code provides debtors with the opportunity to either assume or reject executory contracts in existence at the time the bankruptcy petition is filed. The bill proposes modifying existing subsections of 11 U.S.C. Â§ 1113 to clarify the requirements for rejection of CBAs and provide a more flexible process for debtors to negotiate with labor groups. * The bill aims to rectify the inequities in the bankruptcy process by allowing labor groups to have a greater say in determining the feasibility of reorganization. * The bill also proposes allowing labor groups to request arbitration rather than a court hearing to determine approval of a debtor's request to reject a CBA, potentially reducing the need for negotiations and increasing flexibility for debtors.

* The report discusses appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2016, focusing on the components of DHS including the Office of the Secretary, Executive Management, Office of the Under Secretary for Management, DHS headquarters consolidation project, Office of the Chief Financial Officer, Office of the Chief Information Officer, Analysis and Operations, and the Office of Inspector General for the department. It provides an overview of the Administration's FY2016 request for Departmental Management and Operations, the appropriations proposed by Congress, and the enacted amounts. The report includes information on provisions throughout the proposed bills and reports that directly affect these functions. The suite of CRS reports on homeland security appropriations tracks legislative action and congressional issues related to DHS appropriations, with particular attention paid to discretionary funding amounts. The reports do not provide in-depth analysis of specific issues related to mandatory funding—such as retirement pay—nor do they systematically follow other legislation related to the authorization or amending of DHS programs, activities, or fee revenues. Discussion of appropriations legislation involves a variety of specialized budgetary concepts. The appendix to CRS Report R44053, Department of Homeland Security Appropriations: FY2016, explains several of these concepts, including budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, offsetting collections, allocations, and adjustments to the discretionary spending caps under the Budget Control Act (P.L. 112-25). A more complete discussion of those terms and the appropriations process in general can be found in CRS Report R42388, The Congressional Appropriations Process: An Introduction , by [author name scrubbed], and the Government Accountability Office's A Glossary of Terms Used in the Federal Budget Process . Except in summary discussions and when discussing total amounts for the bill as a whole, all amounts contained in the suite of CRS reports on homeland security appropriations represent budget authority and are rounded to the nearest million. However, for precision in percentages and totals, all calculations were performed using unrounded data. Data used in this report for FY2015 amounts are derived from the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2015 ( P.L. 114-4 ) and the explanatory statement that accompanied H.R. 240 as printed in the Congressional Record of January 13, 2015, pp. H275-H322. • It discusses the role of trade, trade deficits, offshore outsourcing, overseas investment, and economic restructuring in causing gross job loss, but notes that none typically cause net job loss.
• The text also mentions that barriers to gross job loss, such as trade barriers and offshore outsourcing, can lead to lower gross job gains, making such barriers self-defeating.
• The text concludes by suggesting that policymakers should find the right balance between mitigating risk and maintaining market dynamism in an increasingly fluid labor market.

<summary>Summary of Congressional Efforts to Improve Detention Services for Noncitizens in Immigration Detention</summary>

* The U.S. government has introduced legislation aimed at improving medical care for detainees in immigration detention.
* The Consolidated Security, Disaster Assistance, and Continuing Appropriations Act, 2009 (P.L. 110-329) appropriated $2 million for the Office of Professional Responsibility to conduct an immediate comprehensive review of medical care provided to ICE detainees.
* The bill also directed ICE to implement recommendations from the Government Accountability Office (GAO) to improve medical services.
* The Detainee Basic Medical Care Act of 2008, H.R. 5950, was introduced by Representative Zoe Lofgren and introduced by Senator Robert Menendez.
* The bills would have required the Secretary of Homeland Security (DHS) to establish procedures for timely and effective delivery of medical and mental health care to immigration detainees, ensuring continuity of care throughout the detainee's detention.
* The procedures would have addressed all health needs, including primary care, emergency care, prenatal care, dental care, eye care, and mental health care.
* The bills would have required the Secretary of DHS to establish an administrative appeals process for denials of medical or mental health care.
* The bills would have required the Secretary of DHS to report to the Inspector Generals of the Departments of Homeland Security and Justice on detainee deaths no later than 48 hours after the death of the detainee.
* The bills would have required an annual report to Congress detailing any detainee deaths during the previous fiscal year.

• The MCA is a new foreign aid initiative created by the United States, aimed at supporting low- and lower-middle-income countries. It is not intended to replace existing aid programs but to complement them. <summary>
• The MCA will be a performance-driven program, focusing on IDA-eligible, low-income countries. It will be divided into three clusters based on income level and World Bank borrowing status. <summary>
• The MCA will be authorized by the President in FY2004, with a $1.3 billion request for FY2004 and $5 billion for FY2006. It will be funded by $1.3 billion in FY2004 and $800 million in FY2006. <summary>
• The MCA will be implemented by the Millennium Challenge Corporation, supervised by the Board of Directors chaired by the Secretary of State. It will be managed by the MCC, which will be supervised by the Board of Directors. <summary>

* The 112th Congress is considering an omnibus farm bill that will establish the direction of agricultural policy for the next several years. The Senate Agriculture Committee approved its version of the 2012 omnibus farm bill on April 26, 2012, and officially filed the measure on May 24, 2012. After the bill was filed, more than 300 amendments were proposed for consideration on the Senate floor. By mid-June, an agreement was reached to limit the debate to 77 of the proposed amendments, of which 45 were adopted between June 19 and June 21. The full Senate approved S. 3240, as amended, by a vote of 64-35 on June 21. The House Agriculture Committee completed markup of its version of the farm bill (H.R. 6083) on July 11, 2012, and approved the amended measure by a 35-11 vote. Nearly 100 amendments were offered for committee consideration, of which nearly half were adopted by the committee. The House bill was officially filed and reported by the committee on September 13, 2012. Within their 12 titles, the five-year House and Senate farm bills would reshape the structure of farm commodity support, expand crop insurance coverage, consolidate conservation programs, revise the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (formerly food stamps), and extend authority to appropriate funds for many U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) discretionary programs through FY2017.

Congress has historically used commemorative legislation to name federal buildings, post offices, postage stamps, and other public works. Legislation requiring legislation to name post offices or other federal buildings is waived by unanimous consent on at least one occasion. Commemorative legislation can be used to name post offices for individuals, groups, and events, such as the establishment of a national memorial or the creation of a commemorative commission. Commemorative legislation can also be used to honor individuals, groups, and events, such as the creation of a national holiday or the establishment of a commemorative commission. Members may give floor speeches, send flags, and purchase American flags to honor constituents or groups. Members may also use official funds to purchase flags flown over the Capitol building. The House and Senate have different rules regarding commemorative legislation, with the House allowing bills to be considered under suspension of the rules and the Senate prohibiting consideration of commemorative legislation without a minimum number of bipartisan cosponsors.
</summary>

<summary>Summary of the 2008 Lacey Act Amendments</summary>

* The 2008 Lacey Act Amendments were enacted in 2008 to address game poaching and wildlife laundering, among other issues.
* The Lacey Act regulates the trade of wildlife and plants and creates penalties for violations.
* The amendments addressed existing violations and introduced new ones, including nonindigenous plants and violations of foreign laws pertaining to certain conservation actions and other activities involving plants and plant products.
* The amendments expanded the definition of a plant to include nonindigenous plants, requiring importers to submit an import declaration to U. S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) at the time of importation.
* The amendments made it unlawful for any person to import, export, transport, sell, receive, acquire, or purchase in interstate or foreign commerce any plant taken, possessed, transported, or sold in violation of any law or regulation of any state, or in violation of any foreign law.
* The amendments made it unlawful for any person to falsify or submit falsified documents related to any plant or plant product covered by the act, and to import certain plants and plant products without an import declaration.

* The 2002 Farm Security and Rural Investment Act (FSRIA) provides new long-term counter-cyclical support for grains and cotton, replacing target prices and deficiencypayments with fixed, "direct payments" to farmers. Both types of payments will be available to producers with annual agreements with USDA. The measure maintains marketing assistance loans and loan deficiencypayments as they are now, with changes in most loan rates. The new law, which covers the 2002-2007 crop years, brings soybeans and the minor oilseeds (e.g., sunflowers, etc.) fully under the support program rules that apply to grains and cotton. In a major departure from the past, FSRIA redrew the support system to operate like that for grains, oilseeds, and cotton, instead of the traditional system of peanut marketing quotas and nonrecourse price support loans. The new counter-cyclical program will be decoupled from current output, with producer payments not tied to current production or prices. * The 1994 Uruguay Round Agreement on Agriculture (URAA) obligates countries to discipline their agricultural subsidy programs and reduce import barriers to promote more open trade. Under the URAA, the United States is committed to providing subsidies of no more than $19.1 billion per year through domestic farm policies with the most potential to distort production and trade. The URAA contains detailed rules for how countries should determine which of their programs must be counted toward their assigned subsidy limits (e.g., $19.1 billion for the United States). Generally, however, programs that are tied to current prices or current production must be counted (these are called "amber box" policies). * The new counter-cyclical assistance in the 2002 law focuses on the "major" commodities -- grains, cotton, oilseeds, peanuts, and milk. These generally are the most widely produced, but that still leaves much of U.S. agriculture ineligible for such payments, raising questions of equity among commodities, and of the potential for distorting production toward items that might receive more support (contributing to surplus production). * The 1994 URAA also includes a provision for the United States to provide direct payments to farmers who are unable to produce any particular crop now to receive the payments. • The study investigates the expression and function of tgm2, a marker for m2 macrophages, in rat renal allografts during acute rejection episodes. It demonstrates that tgm2 is overexpressed by mononuclear leukocytes, predominantly by activated monocytes, accumulating in the vascular bed of rat renal allografts on day 9 after transplantation. The study also shows that tgm2 expression is induced in graft tissue upon allogenic transplantation, but no quantitative changes were detected in the protein level. <summary>Summary of the Study: Sublingual Nitroglycerin Spray Increases Time to Onset of Moderate Angina During Exercise</summary>

• The study aimed to evaluate the effect of sublingual nitroglycerin spray on the time to onset of moderate angina during exercise in patients with stable angina.

• The study included 61 patients with stable angina who were randomized to receive either sublingual nitroglycerin spray or placebo.

• The results showed that sublingual nitroglycerin spray significantly increased the time to onset of moderate angina during exercise compared to placebo.

• The study also found that sublingual nitroglycerin spray was well tolerated and associated with a significant improvement in exercise tolerance.

• The results suggest that sublingual nitroglycerin spray may be a useful adjunct to optimal medical therapy in patients with stable angina.

• The study's findings support the use of sublingual nitroglycerin spray as a nitrate therapy for patients with stable angina who are being managed with optimal medical therapy.

* The study aimed to investigate the presence of motor and sensory deficits in the ipsilateral upper limb and their correlation with each other in patients with stroke using a tracking and reposition sense test.
* Fifty hemiparetic stroke patients (25 with right brain injury and 25 with left brain injury) were recruited consecutively from a local rehabilitation hospital.
* The inclusion criteria included first-ever stroke confirmed by medical history and brain MRI, right-handed individuals verified by the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory, no symptoms of unilateral neglect or hemianopsia, no cognitive problems (Mini-Mental State Examination > 24 points), no apraxic behavior (Motor Apraxia Score > 11 points), and no musculoskeletal dysfunction in the unaffected upper limb.
* The tracking and joint position sense tests were conducted for the hand ipsilateral to the damaged hemisphere of the patients, and the corresponding hand of the same side of the control subjects.
* All subjects were seated in front of a table, with the forearm supported and the elbow flexed at 90 degrees. The potentiometer was used to measure the accuracy of movement and proprioceptive sense in the metacarpophalangeal joints.
* The accuracy index (ai) was analyzed, taking into account the differences in the excursion of the target and response waves. Three practice trials were provided after one demonstration, using sine waves different from the actual test to prevent a learning effect.
* The joint position sense was evaluated on the mp joint ipsilateral to the damaged brain hemisphere of the patients, and the corresponding joint on the control subjects.
* The same experimental apparatus and environment were used for the tracking task. The subjects were instructed to actively reproduce the position of the mp joint which was被动 positioned by the examiner.
* The results showed that the stroke group showed a lower accuracy index in the mp joint than the control group. A higher score of reposition errors in the joint reposition test compared to sensory function was observed in the stroke group, compared to the control group.
* The statistical analysis indicated that both measures in the stroke group were significantly different from the control group (p < 0.05).

• The Millennium Cohort Study, the largest prospective study using primary data collection ever undertaken by the Department of Defense, began in 2001 with the objective to collect and evaluate data on health, behavioral risk factors, and occupational characteristics related to military service that may be associated with adverse health outcomes. The study included 77,047 participants from the first enrollment cycle, spanning 2001-2003, and 55,021 participants at year 3 and 54,790 at year 6. The study was approved by the Naval Health Research Center Institutional Review Board and informed consent was obtained from all participants. The study was conducted in compliance with all applicable federal regulations governing the protection of human subjects in research (protocol NHRC.2000.0007). The study was conducted in a large population-based study of active duty and reserve/national guard U.S. military personnel from all service branches. The study found that trouble sleeping and sleep apnea are associated with higher diabetes risk, independent of multiple diabetes risk factors and several mental health conditions. The study also found that self-reported sleep apnea was associated with a significantly higher risk for diabetes even after adjustment for other sleep characteristics, BMI, and mental health conditions. The study's findings suggest that the associations between type 2 diabetes risk and mental health conditions and sleep characteristics, if causal, may involve different pathways.
</summary>

<summary>
In prosthodontic practice, limited mouth opening in patients is a common occurrence. Prosthetic rehabilitation of patients with restricted mouth opening due to various conditions, such as surgical treatments of orofacial carcinoma, cleft lip, trauma, burns, plummer vinson syndrome, scleroderma, trismus, rheumatism, temporomandibular joint dysfunction syndrome, oral submucous fibrosis, and any damage to masticatory muscles, presents significant challenges at all stages. A maximal oral opening smaller than the size of a complete denture can make prosthetic treatment challenging. The treatment plan includes sectional maxillary and mandibular final impression procedures, followed by fabricating maxillary hinged and mandibular sectional and hinged complete dentures. The primary impression for maxillary arch is taken using the smallest size edentulous stock tray with impression compound (YDents; MDM Corp.), and the impression is prepared using proper disinfection (1:213 iodophore) and sectioned into two halves. The sectional impression tray is prepared using dental stone (Denstone, grade III) and the second sectional impression tray is assembled. Wax rims are prepared over the denture bases. The wax rim is not prepared in the mandibular anterior region due to the presence of press buttons over the anterior segment of the ridge. The teeth arrangement is done using index wax, and the denture is processed with heat cure acrylic resin (Trevlon; Dentsply). The mandibular hinge denture is placed back over the master cast and the index of the mandibular denture is made with irreversible hydrocolloid (Alginate, Zelgan 2002, Dentsply). <summary>Summary of Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) Pathogenesis, Treatment, and Biomarkers</summary>

• Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the sixth most common malignancy worldwide and the third most common cause of global cancer-related mortality. It disproportionately impacts developing countries and males, with 85% of cases occurring in Africa and Asia, and a worldwide male: female sex ratio of 2.4. Risk factors for HCC include chronic liver inflammation from hepatitis B and C infections, autoimmune hepatitis, excessive alcohol use, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis, environmental carcinogens, and genetic metabolic diseases like hemochromatosis and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

• HCC is relatively refractory to cytotoxic chemotherapy, likely due to overexpression of multidrug-resistant genes, protein products like heat shock 70 and p-glycoprotein, and p53 mutations. Currently, systemic therapeutic options in locally advanced or metastatic HCC are limited to sorafenib, an oral multikinase inhibitor targeting raf kinase, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) receptor tyrosine kinase signaling.

• HCC development is multifactorial and is influenced by dysregulation of multiple pathways including Wnt/b-catenin, mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), phosphatidylinositol-3 (PI3K)/Akt/mTOR, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) signaling. The hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) axis is crucial for normal processes like embryogenesis, organogenesis, and postnatal tissue repair.

• HGF is a ligand for the met receptor, also known as cellular met or cmet, and plays a key role in mammalian development, including morphogenesis, mitogenesis, and motogenesis. It is regulated by paracrine ligand delivery, ligand activation, and autocrine signaling.

• Dysplastic nodules progress to early HCC through cumulative genetic alterations, while advanced HCC often involves intrahepatic metastasis and portal vein invasion. Molecular alterations implicated in HCC development include mutations in oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes, epigenetic alterations, chromosomal changes, and aberrant activation of signaling cascades.

• The molecular pathogenesis of HCC is multifactorial and is influenced by dysregulation of multiple pathways including Wnt/b-catenin

<summary>Diabetes and Cancer: A Complex Association</summary>
Diabetes and cancer are two closely related conditions that have been the subject of intense debate for over a century. The length of this debate suggests that any such associations are relatively weak, and most practicing diabetologists do not view cancer as a specific, diabetes-associated risk. The association between diabetes and cancer is further complicated by the fact that insulin, which is increasingly used in the management of type 2 diabetes, is used in various forms to treat the condition. The study of glargine, a newer form of insulin, has shown potential mitogenic and anti-apoptotic effects on cancer cells, but the clinical implications remain controversial. The association between diabetes and cancer is also complicated by the fact that the association between diabetes and cancer is not directly related to the risk of cancer. The evidence presented in the diabetologia papers is insufficient to establish that there is a case to answer, but it is important to consider the long-term effects of diabetes itself, insulin treatment, and specifically, glargine, on cancer development. Further research is needed to address the relationship between diabetes, insulin, insulin analogues, and secretagogues, and to explore potentially protective effects of metformin and the most tantalizing question: why is diabetes not more strongly associated with cancer?</summary>

<summary>Research on Antireflection Layers in High-Efficiency Solar Cells</summary>

* Antireflection (AR) technology plays a crucial role in the fabrication of high-efficiency solar cells by increasing light coupling into the active region of devices. Generally, a relatively low-light reflectivity can be obtained for crystalline silicon solar cells by combining surface texturization with six-nanometer thin-film deposition. However, to further reduce the light reflectivity for the improvement of solar cell efficiency, various nanostructures with size comparable to the wavelength of the incident light have been proposed, such as photonic crystals, porous structures, plasmoids, monics, and dielectric nanoparticles. All these nanostructures should be based on wide-bandgap materials that themselves cannot absorb sunlight. The zno material has a wide-bandgap, which has been widely used in fields such as photocatalysis and optoelectronic nanodevices. For photovoltaic applications, the zno nanostructures as antireflective layers can be fabricated by various approaches, such as pulsed laser deposition, chemical vapor deposition, vapor-liquid-solid growth, hydrothermal method, and electrochemical deposition technique. The zno nanowiskers (nws) with different lengths have been grown by the seeding and growth two-step process, and integrated into the fabrication of CZochralski silicon solar cells based on the current standard celling technology. The density and length of the zno nws have been optimized for the improvement of solar cell performances by controlling the time of growth. The results show that the efficiency of CZ silicon solar cell can be improved by a value of 3% relatively using the zno nws as the antireflective layer in practice. The starting samples are p-type CZ silicon solar cells fabricated by a standard process including surface texturization, phosphorus diffusion, six-nanometer film deposition, screen printing, and metallization. The seed layer of zno was first deposited on the front surface of solar cells by a magnetron sputtering system. The deposition temperature is 150°C, and the seed layer thickness is about 10 nm. After protecting the parts without the zno seed film with waterproof tapes, the samples were immersed in the solution of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (zn(no3)26h2o) and (ch2)6n4 mixture for 30 to 60 minutes for the growth of zno nw. Parkinson's disease (PD) is the most common neurodegenerative parkinsonian syndrome characterized by degeneration of both dopaminergic and non-dopaminergic neurons with intracytoplasmic inclusions known as Lewy bodies. Although the clinical diagnosis of PD is often straightforward and robust, the correct diagnosis can be challenging, especially in clinically mild or uncertain cases. Molecular imaging techniques using PET or single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) have improved diagnostic accuracy. Dopamine transporter (DAT) ligands 24 and sympathetic innervation of the heart 1,5 have become popular and widely used in clinical practice. Schistosomidae, a diverse group of parasitic flatworms, includes several species with complex life cycles. The development of schistosomiasis, a chronic and debilitating disease, is considered one of the most serious public health issues and a second most prevalent tropical disease with high morbidity. Schistosomiasis is endemic in 77 countries and its transmission is dependent on intermediate hosts. The study of schistosomiasis involves genomics and transcriptomics, which provide insights into the evolutionary history and biology of the parasite. <summary>Summary of the Review on Outcome Measures Used in Stroke Self-Mismanagement</summary>

* The review examined the methodological quality of outcome measures used in stroke self-mismanagement according to the criteria outlined by the Cosmin checklist. Consistent with measurement theory, the review explored the validity and reliability of these measures for use in people with stroke, not their general use in broader populations. The review found that no study adopted a measure of stroke self-management attitudes or behaviors, which will first be addressed. The range and number of different published outcome measures adopted by studies in this review may suggest a current lack of consensus regarding the appropriate measures to assist evaluation of stroke self-mismanagement. The review highlights that the reported theoretical drivers within stroke self-mismanagement are unclear, not least because they are often not explicitly stated by researchers. The heterogeneity of the outcome measures utilised by stroke self-mismanagement may indicate a difficulty in determining the expected outcomes of stroke self-mismanagement. A systematic review demonstrated that interventions with specific aims, such as reduced systolic blood pressure in hypertension or glycosylated haemoglobin levels in diabetes, produced greater effect sizes than those without defined outcomes. Further work is therefore warranted to conceptualise stroke self-mismanagement and examine the theoretical premises supporting such interventions, and expected outcomes so that appropriate outcome measures which accurately reflect the concept can be selected and/or developed. The revive survey suggests that effective patient education can improve patient adherence and satisfaction with vva treatment, but it also emphasizes the importance of providing simple screening questions during routine visits to identify those in need of treatment.

The role of endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (dx / ha) has expanded as an alternative to open surgery for observation protocols using prophylactic antibiotics. Reports of expanded use to patients of all ages and grades of vur even in the presence of duplication, ureterocele, or other lower tract anomalies are published worldwide. The initial success rate was quoted as 68% and is still mentioned on the current website. The original subureteric injection technique (sting) has evolved to the intraureteric injection technique introduced by the Atlanta group using hydrodistention-implantation technique (hit). The intraoperative cystogram was developed to detect occult vur in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections (utis) after a negative standard voiding cystogram.

This may be associated with a general reduction of bacterial diversity and shifts toward certain bacterial groups and the appearance of previously unidentified species. The gut microbiota has been attributed a role in the development of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (Nalfld). The interdependence between microbiota, metabolism, and inflammation is also highlighted. The gut flora can affect host responses, including host genotype, environment, and diet. The microbiota exerts its effects on the intestine through bacterial signaling molecules and metabolic products. Components of the microbiome can also enter the circulation, be transported to various organs, and potentiate multiple effects in these organs. The gut brain axis can circumvent intestinal absorption and may allow the microbiome to directly affect the brain. The oral cavity has one distinct advantage over the gut tract: accessibility. <summary>Summary of the Source Document</summary>

* Genetic variation contributes to both disease susceptibility and treatment response.
* Genome-wide association studies (GWA) have enabled rapid discovery of genetic variants contributing to the pathogenesis of complex genetic diseases.
* Promoting personalized medicine will improve medical decision-making.
* Although use of the term personalized medicine is often limited to the identification of optimal drug and dosage for subgroup patients, current personalized medicine applications are far more broad and might include situations of withholding treatment, preventive interventions, or targeted treatment options for individual patients.
* In prostate cancer, for example, dna biomarker tests may be used to determine whether treatment may be safely delayed for a period of watchful waiting.
* In contrast, in other instances, genetic profiles may be used to determine preventive interventions.
* This approach is already used for some forms of hereditary cancer, in which individual genetic testing is the basis for deciding on specific, sometimes very radical interventions such as preventive surgery (Kroll et al., 2008).
* Beyond treatment schemes that are applied identically across large subgroups of patients, to which some authors have applied the term "stratified medicine" (Trusheim et al., 2007).
* Other personalized medicine applications offer targeted treatment options for individual patients.
* Anti-inflammatory therapies, such as anti-tnf, anti-IL-6, or anti-IL-1, are thought to be effective in inflammatory diseases, such as Crohn's disease (Buchner et al., 2008).
* Other molecules seem suitable for use as anti-inflammatory therapy as well.
* To choose one or a combination of different anti-inflammatory therapies, the physician might first obtain the genetic profile of a patient by sequencing.
* Depending on the individual DNA profile, the physician might select the anti-inflammatory combination therapy, which may include many different molecules.
* However, foundational to personalized medicine, biological markers, biomarkers for short, are diversely defined in the literature.
* Gallo et al. (2011) summarize some of the definitions, and observe that the most commonly adopted definition states that a biomarker is any substance or biological structure that can be measured in the human body and may influence, explain or predict the incidence or outcome of disease.
* However, it is a matter of debate whether the qualification that biomarkers must be measured in the human body is a reasonable limitation.

<summary>Our study aimed to determine whether clinical outcomes after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (eac) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (escc) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in different proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the aurka (rs2273535), erbb2 (rs1136201), mdm2 (rs2279744), cdh1 (rs5030625), cdkn2a (rs11515), and tp73 (rs2273953) were genotyped in a consecutive cohort of 346 esophageal cancer patients who underwent surgical resection with curative intent. The association with disease-free survival (DFS) was analyzed using Kaplan-Meier curves and cox regression, adjusting for potential confounders. Univariate analysis showed no significant associations between the tested polymorphisms and DFS in patients with eac or escc. However, multivariate analysis revealed that patients with eac carrying the heterozygous mdm2 (rs2279744) t / g genotype had significantly improved DFS compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype (adjusted hazard ratio (aHR) 0.63, 95% confidence interval (CI) [0.450.88], p < 0.007). Patients with eac harboring the homozygous cdh1 (rs5030625) ga / ga genotype had a significantly reduced survival as compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype (adjusted hazard ratio (aHR) 4.0, 95% CI [1.411], p < 0.008). In a large cohort of esophageal cancer patients, the mdm2 t / g and cdh1 ga / ga genotype confer risk of death in patients with eac. These data suggest that inter-individual differences in germ-line DNA have an impact on DFS in patients with eac. Many therapeutic options are used to treat esophageal cancer, but traditionally, surgery is used most frequently to obtain loco-regional control and long-term survival. • The prevalence of oral candidiasis (opc) in HIV patients is high, with approximately 38% of patients having oral lesions. 
• The most common occlusal lesions are erythematous patches or white, scrapable lesions, often associated with hiv infection. 
• The diagnosis of oral lesions is based on clinical examination and laboratory tests, and is often associated with hiv-associated oral lesions. 
• The prevalence of oral candidiasis in HIV patients is higher in patients with cd4 + counts below 200 cells/mm or a high viral load (>10,000 copies/ml).

<summary>Summary of the Study on Surrogate Variables for Neuronal Pathway Dysfunction in Advanced Diabetic Foot Ulcers</summary>

• The study evaluated several surrogate variables for predicting wound healing in advanced diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) using intralesional rhegf injections.
• The authors tested the surrogate variables proposed for neuropathic DFUs and explored their correlation with complete healing during follow-up for 1 year.
• The study included 13 patients randomized to intralesional rhegf injections at 75 g or 25 g, three times per week, and 16 patients to placebo.
• The results showed that the 25- and 75-g dose levels were used according to the product label, and rhegf treatment was administered up to complete granulation or a maximum of 8 weeks.
• The study confirmed that the predictive property of percent area change, log healing rate, and ratio of log area could be extrapolated to more complicated, ischemic, larger, and Wagner grade 3 or 4 ulcers.
• The cutoff points for classification were not the same, with the correct classification percent in the present series being < 70% and negative pvs < 60.
• The extrapolation of the cutoff points proposed in the present work has the limitation of the small sample size analyzed, so further research is needed.
• The study provides the first evidence for the use of granulation tissue development as a predictor of wound healing in advanced DFUs.
• The surrogate markers can easily be applied by clinicians due to the measurement of the proportion of wound area covered by granulation tissue being part of routine clinical care. </summary>

• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, characterized by network vascular inflammation, demyelination, and axonal damage. It is a common disorder affecting young adults and is diagnosed in approximately 85% to 90% of cases.
• MS is classified into relapsing-remitting and progressive forms, with relapsing-remitting being the most common. The exact cause of MS is unknown, but several factors, including genetic and environmental factors, are believed to play a role.
• Researchers have investigated the role of interleukin-25 (IL-25) in MS. IL-25 is a cytokine that plays a key role in stimulating and developing T helper 2 (Th2) responses. It is involved in the control of the immune system, including the endothelial cells, th1 and th17 cells, and the main cells involved in the pathogenic activities of the immune system.
• The c424c / a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene has been identified as a potential candidate for investigation in the pathogenesis of MS. The polymorphism may be associated with MS, and further research is needed to confirm this.
• The study evaluated the association between the c424c / a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and MS in an Iranian population. The results showed that 1 to 2% of patients had the aa genotype, while 16 to 47% had the ac and 47 to 66% had the cc genotype. The chi-square test revealed that the frequency distribution of genotypes was not statistically different between patients with MS and controls.

The study evaluated the entire aorta diameter, from the thoracic aorta to the abdomen aorta, using axial images of non-contrast CT scans in a population with multiple risk factors for both coronary heart disease (CHD) and aortic aneurysms (AA). The study population included high-risk individuals but blood pressure and serum lipids were well controlled, with prevalence of taa being considerably high and associated with various clinical factors, including older age, larger aortic root, higher diastolic blood pressure, and absence of dyslipidemia. The study also found that taa was associated with the absence of dyslipidemia, while aaa was significantly associated with the presence of dyslipidemia. The results highlight the importance of understanding the relationship between taa and aaa, as they are both associated with increased age and hypertension. The study also found that taa prevalence continuously increases, and is thought to be related to increased age and hypertension in the general population. The prevalence of taa was significantly higher in elderly Korean males with hypertension compared to other populations, and the study suggests that race influences aaa prevalence and that asians generally have a low prevalence of aaa. The results of the study highlight the need for clear definitions of the usefulness of routine screening for aaa among Asian non-smokers.
</summary>

• The study aimed to investigate whether liquid-based surepath preparation for endometrial cytology test (eCT) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium.
• The study was performed from November 2011 to May 2014 at the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department of Peking University First Hospital and was approved by the hospital ethics committee.
• The risk factors for endometrial cancer included age, high estrogen levels, and family history of cancer.
• The study included 1514 patients with endometrial cancer risk factors, and 375 underwent endometrial cytology sampling.
• The results showed that the sap-1 sampling method provided more adequate materials for cytology than d & c or hysteroscopic biopsy.
• The accuracy of sap-1 sampling for detecting endometrial precursors and carcinomas was estimated at 91.7%, sensitivity at 73.6%, specificity at 94.9%, ppv at 71.9%, and npv at 95.3%.
• The study demonstrated that the sap-1 sampler combined with liquid-based surepath preparation method is a reliable diagnostic method for endometrial cancer and its precursor.
• The study showed that the sap-1 sampling method can reduce unnecessary d & c and improve the accuracy of endometrial cytology.
</summary>

• The global population is aging, with the elderly being particularly vulnerable to cardiovascular diseases.
• Endothelial dysfunction is a key factor in the development of cardiovascular diseases, characterized by reduced vasodilator substance output and increased endothelium-derived contracting factors.
• Exercise has been shown to improve endothelial function and reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases in older adults.
• The endothelium plays a crucial role in regulating blood pressure, oxygenation, and inflammation, and its dysfunction is associated with increased risk of cardiovascular diseases.
• The mechanisms underlying endothelial aging include oxidative stress and inflammation, and exercise can restore endothelial function and reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases.
• Regular aerobic exercise can slow down the aging process and improve endothelial function, potentially reducing the risk of cardiovascular diseases in older adults.
